ancestors.content:
…many…are deeply distraught about the #cost of #food. …But as painful as #foodflation is, it may just be an early ripple of the kind of disruption to the #FoodSystem that’s coming. The scale of these changes will be breathtaking. Their #global #consequences will be profound &…they will change what’s…on our kitchen tables.

#Climate #ClimateChange #weather #ExtremeWeather #heat #agriculture #sustainability

card.title: Opinion | What to Eat on a Burning Planet
card.description: The future of the food supply is uncertain. Let’s look at solutions.

descendants.content:
Like it or not, our produce aisles are on the brink of transformation.

At the same time, #agriculture itself is putting greater & greater pressure on the #environment & the #climate. Though the #organic & #plant-based #food movements have helped shift production & consumption patterns ever so slightly, we remain dependent on a largely #unsustainable #food system that’s destroying precious #resources as it races to feed the #world.

#ClimateChange #weather #ExtremeWeather #heat #sustainability

descendants.content:
A few countries are sensing that they have to innovate: #Brazil has an #IndustrialFarm that produces record yields w/ #regenerative #farming. But hardly anyone in the #US is talking about the coming crisis — & how to fix a broken system.…

The idea behind What to Eat on a Burning Planet,…is to push #lawmakers, #scientists, #farmers & #consumers to confront the growing strain on #GlobalFoodSupply & the natural systems it depends on & to advance a range of solutions.

#ClimateChange #agriculture

descendants.content:
@Nonilex

#SolutionsForClimateChange: #Agrivoltaics and #WaruWaru

The solutions for a big part of the planet have been with us since 1977 and 300 BCE: Agrivoltaics and Waru Waru, also called #sucacollos.
This is true in regions experiencing extreme rainfalls due to #AtmosphericRivers, like the US West Coast, or monsoons.

descendants.content: @Nonilex I live in New Zealand, where our intensive agriculture industry makes the argument about "racing to feed the world". Sadly, this is not the case. Our industry is racing to supply meat and dairy products to large corporate food processors and supermarkets at the best price, who are actually only feeding the proportion of the world that can afford their products. The people who need them most never get to taste our produce.

account.note:
Embarrassed about the mess I and my lot have made of the planet and society. Hoping to tidy up a bit before I go.
Systems thinker; I see them everywhere and am fascinated by them, especially the systems of the natural world. Have been described as an "intuitive visionary".
Not qualified to call myself an expert in anything, but I like to think I know stuff.
Pragmatist. Interests: #Geek #ClassicRock, #HappyLife #Science #ClimateChange #sustainability, #equity, #Future #consciousconsumer

descendants.content:
@Nonilex
Extreme rainfall and new roads and developments - massive landslides, trapping killing, houses waterlogged. India tough times. Many railroad causing derailment.
Modernization has cost India. Billionaires have no priority

@Nonilex I know that greens especially are (a) harder to grow as temperatures rise and water gets more scarce and (b) exquisitely regional, in the sense that what greens a home gardener without fancy ag-tech and the full chemical suite can readily grow varies not just state by state but county by county.

With those disclaimers, if everybody in the country had my specific summertime climate challenges, we would be looking at a future with a metric fuckton of swiss chard in it. *cronch*cronch*
